vibeCoding.definition: A development approach where AI agents handle most coding tasks while you provide guidance, make decisions, and verify the results. Think of it as pair programming with AI!
vibeCoding.example: Instead of memorizing syntax, you describe what you want and AI writes the code for you.

react.definition: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It lets you create reusable components that update efficiently when your data changes.
react.example: React powers apps like Facebook, Instagram, and Netflix.

vite.definition: A lightning-fast build tool that starts your development server instantly and updates your changes in milliseconds. Much faster than older tools!
vite.example: When you save a file, Vite shows your changes almost immediately.

typescript.definition: JavaScript with type safety. It catches errors before you even run your code, making development faster and less buggy.
typescript.example: TypeScript knows if you're trying to use a number as text and warns you.

api.definition: Application Programming Interface - a way for different software programs to talk to each other. Like a menu at a restaurant: you order from the menu, and the kitchen makes it.
api.example: When you check weather on your phone, it uses an API to get data from a weather service.

restApi.definition: A common style of API that uses HTTP requests (like your web browser uses) to get, create, update, or delete data.
restApi.example: GET /products fetches product data, POST /orders creates a new order.

microsoftGraph.definition: Microsoft's API that lets you access data from Microsoft 365 services like Teams, Outlook, OneDrive, and Azure Active Directory.
microsoftGraph.example: Use Graph API to show a user's calendar or recent emails in your app.

azure.definition: Microsoft's cloud computing platform. Think of it as renting powerful computers and services from Microsoft instead of buying and maintaining your own.
azure.example: Deploy your web app to Azure so anyone can access it on the internet.

tenant.definition: In Microsoft 365/Azure, a tenant is your organization's instance. It's like your company's private section of Microsoft's cloud.
tenant.example: When you sign in with your work email, you're accessing your company's tenant.

msal.definition: Microsoft Authentication Library - code that handles signing users in with their Microsoft accounts and getting permission to access their data.
msal.example: MSAL shows the 'Sign in with Microsoft' button and handles the login process.

environmentVariables.definition: Secret configuration values that change based on where your code runs (development vs production). Never put passwords directly in code!
environmentVariables.example: VITE_API_KEY stores your API key separately from your code.

npm.definition: Node Package Manager - a huge library of free code packages that you can use in your projects. Why reinvent the wheel?
npm.example: 'npm install react' downloads React so you can use it in your project.

git.definition: Version control system that tracks every change to your code. Like 'Track Changes' in Word, but way more powerful.
git.example: If you break something, Git lets you go back to a working version.

vscode.definition: Visual Studio Code - a free, powerful code editor from Microsoft. It's where you'll write, edit, and run your code.
vscode.example: VS Code has autocomplete, debugging, and thousands of extensions.

mcpServers.definition: Model Context Protocol servers that give GitHub Copilot access to specialized knowledge and up-to-date documentation.
mcpServers.example: Context7 server provides Copilot with current library docs, so it suggests modern patterns.

beastMode.definition: GitHub Copilot's power mode for complex tasks. It provides thorough, production-ready solutions with detailed explanations.
beastMode.example: Use Beast Mode when building complete features or solving complex problems.

planMode.definition: A strategic approach to prompting where you describe the entire architecture before building. Gets AI thinking about the big picture.
planMode.example: Describe your whole app structure, then let AI generate each piece.

component.definition: A reusable piece of UI in React. Like LEGO blocks - you build your app by combining components.
component.example: A Button component can be reused throughout your app with different labels and colors.

props.definition: Short for 'properties' - data you pass into a React component. Like function parameters, but for UI.
props.example: <Button color='blue' label='Click me' /> passes color and label as props.

state.definition: Data that can change over time in your React component. When state changes, React re-renders the UI automatically.
state.example: A counter's current value is state - click a button, state updates, UI updates.

hook.definition: Special React functions that let you use features like state and lifecycle methods. They start with 'use'.
hook.example: useState, useEffect, useContext are all hooks.

tailwind.definition: A utility-first CSS framework. Instead of writing CSS files, you apply style classes directly to HTML elements.
tailwind.example: <div className='bg-blue-500 text-white p-4 rounded'> styles a blue box.

jsx.definition: JavaScript XML - a syntax that lets you write HTML-like code in JavaScript. React's secret sauce!
jsx.example: const button = <button>Click me</button> looks like HTML but it's JavaScript.

deployment.definition: The process of putting your app on the internet so others can use it. Like publishing a book, but for software.
deployment.example: Deploy to Azure Static Web Apps to get a public URL for your app.

cicd.definition: Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment - automatically testing and deploying your code when you make changes.
cicd.example: Push code to GitHub, tests run automatically, if they pass, deploy to production.

dataverse.definition: Microsoft's cloud database designed for Power Platform apps. Stores your business data with built-in security and relationships.
dataverse.example: Store customer records, orders, and products in Dataverse tables.

pcf.definition: PowerApps Component Framework - lets you create custom controls for Power Apps using React, Angular, or vanilla JavaScript.
pcf.example: Build a fancy chart component in React and use it in your Power App.

powerApps.definition: Microsoft's low-code/no-code platform for building business apps. Now you can add custom code components too!
powerApps.example: Build an expense approval app without traditional coding (or enhance it with code components).

modelDrivenApp.definition: A type of Power App that automatically generates UI based on your data model. Great for complex business apps.
modelDrivenApp.example: Define customer and order tables, Power Apps creates forms and views automatically.

canvasApp.definition: A type of Power App where you design the UI pixel-by-pixel. Maximum flexibility and creativity.
canvasApp.example: Drag and drop buttons, forms, and galleries to design your app's exact look.

solution.definition: In Power Platform, a container for all your components (apps, tables, flows) that you can move between environments.
solution.example: Build in dev environment, export solution, import to production.

customPage.definition: A full-screen page in model-driven apps where you can use React and custom code. Perfect for embedding Code Components!
customPage.example: Add a custom dashboard page with interactive charts to your model-driven app.

pacCli.definition: Power Platform CLI - command-line tools for developing, testing, and deploying Power Platform components.
pacCli.example: pac pcf init creates a new Code Component project.
